Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Spin Physics `by design' in quantum dot molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical
Modern electronic devices (e.g. computer hard drives) use "spin" to store information. Other optoelectronic devices (e.g. lasers) use light to transmit information. This project investigates new materials that could integrate these two functions in a single system. We will explore the properties of coupled pairs of semiconductor quantum dots that behave like molecules with unique and tunable properties. The results will provide the scientific foundation for building faster and more powerful computing, information transmission and information storage devices. The project will train graduate students in the conduct of research. It will also help to inspire and educate younger students by bringing hands-on scientific experiments into K-12 classrooms.

Technical
Coupled pairs of semiconductor quantum dots are called quantum dot molecules because coherent tunneling between the individual quantum dots leads to the formation of molecular states with unique and tunable properties. This project will develop the scientific foundation for predictive design of tailored properties for individual charges confined within quantum dot molecules. To accomplish this objective, the research team is investigating specific changes in the structure, composition and electric field environment of the quantum dot molecule that they hypothesize will lead to new optoelectronic and spin properties. The team will grow designed quantum dot molecules using molecular beam epitaxy and fabricate device structures that allow application of two-dimensional electric field profiles that break the molecular symmetry. The resulting optoelectronic and spin properties will be characterized with optical spectroscopy at low temperatures and in high magnetic fields. The team will develop the computational tools necessary to accurately predict the properties of new quantum dot complexes that incorporate nontraditional materials such as GaBiAs and rare-earth nanoinclusions. Close interaction between theory and experiment will allow refinement and validation of the computational models, setting the stage for predictive engineering of solid state nanostructures with tailored properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Semiconductor materials are widely used in technologies ranging from computer chips to solar panels. The precise material composition, structure, and thickness of the material used must be optimized for the desired application. For example, materials for solar panels must strongly absorb light and efficiently conduct the generated electricity. The work conducted with support from this award is focused on exploring two new types of semiconductor materials and electrical devices. The objective is to understand the ways in which material structure and composition on nanometer length scales leads to the emergent properties and thus to improve computational models for predictive design of these materials for applications. A particular focus for this work was on quantum dot-based materials that could provide a foundation for next-generation computer chips that implement quantum, rather than classical, logic. Quantum logic and quantum information processing offers the possibility to drastically outperform any possible classical computer for certain types of problems, including searching large databases. However, the material platform for such a quantum computing platform remains one of the many very serious challenges.

The spin projection (e.g. up versus down) of a single charge (e.g. electron) trapped in a semiconductor quantum is one of the promising candidates for a qubit, the fundamental unit of quantum information. The primary activities of this project were to simulate, design, create, and study devices based on coupled pairs of semiconductor quantum dots that are expected to provide unique control over the spin and thus to enable a scalable approach to quantum information processing. We developed new ways to computationally simulate the properties of these complexes and showed that a) nontraditional material compositions can improve our ability to control spin properties and b) applied electric fields can be used to control spin without a magnetic field. We developed new techniques for growing semiconductors that include these nontraditional materials (including Er, Tb, and Bi within traditional GaAs semiconductors). Finally, we developed the capacity to simulate and fabricate devices that can apply two-dimensional electric fields to single quantum dots or pairs of quantum dots that are approximately 500 times smaller than the diameter of a human hair. Taken together, these advances provide the capacity to being designing new devices based on these materials for new quantum information processing applications.

With support from this award, five graduate students and two undergraduate students were trained to conduct and report scientific research. In parallel, we developed an extensive partnership with Tarbiyah Islamic School of Delaware. This effort included developing new hands-on educational modules, training teachers and parents from Tarbiyah to use these modules with their students, and providing modules to Tarbiyah for a summer camp with their students.
